awd_titl_txt: Zinc finger methyl-CpG binding proteins: Bimodal regulators of cellular transcription
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary goal of this research is to understand the mechanisms by which gene expression is regulated within the cell. DNA is the long-term storage unit for genetic information, providing instructions for cellular and life functions. Access to different genetic regions is partially regulated by reversible chemical changes to localized regions of the DNA, defined as epigenetic modifications. This project evaluates the role of a small family of proteins, the ZBTB family, that are important in making these epigenetic modifications. The broader impacts for this project include two major aspects: First, the training of graduate students in an interdisciplinary research program that utilizes a broad spectrum of techniques to identify and characterize the three ZBTB. Second, this project includes the development of biochemical and DNA-focused hands-on and inquiry-based activities at The Leonardo, a museum in downtown Salt Lake City. In addition to the broader public, The Leonardo accommodates a significant number of students from underrepresented and underserved groups from Salt Lake Valley schools. It is well recognized that the interest of a child in science is best instilled at an early and impressionable age, and it is expected that development and implementation of hands-on activities will have a long-term significant impact on the state's diversity growth in STEM areas.

DNA methylation is one form of epigenetic modification.  While insight into how the DNA methylation mark is established and removed has been gained, there is only minimal knowledge for the mechanisms by which methyl-CpG binding proteins (MBPs),read DNA methylation marks and translate this information into a specific transcriptional outcome, particularly for the ZBTB MBPs. An understanding for how the ZBTB MBPs modulate transcription is complicated by the fact that they exhibit bimodal DNA recognition, targeting both methylated and sequence-specific non-methylated DNA sites, which affords them the capability of functioning as both transcriptional repressors and activators. Additionally, each of the ZBTB MBPs can interact with multiple co-repressor/-activator protein complexes at target gene sites. Thus, an understanding for how each of these proteins elicits selectivity for their binding partners is central to discerning their role in transcriptional regulation. To investigate this, a combined in vitro biophysical and in cell approach will be utilized to delineate the mechanisms by which this family of MBPs recognize their DNA and proteins targets. The overall goals are to structurally characterize ZBTB protein:DNA interactions to gain mechanistic insight into how each protein preferentially selects DNA targets; to utilize function-specific mutations to probe the molecular basis for bimodal DNA recognition; and to define protein interactomes for each ZBTB MBP. The outcomes of this research will provide an essential foundation for the larger goal of discerning the full mechanisms by which each member of this under studied family of ZBTB MBPs elicits selective gene targeting, recruits specific protein complexes to the target site and alters transcription to provide a particular cellular function.

por.por_cntn:
DNA is the long-term storage unit for genetic information and encoder of instructions for cellular and life functions. Access to different genetic regions is regulated in part by reversible surface chemical alterations to DNA, defined as epigenetic modifications. One prevalent epigenetic modification is the addition of a methyl group (CH3) at specific DNA sites; required for stabilizing genetic material and regulating gene expression. The correlation between DNA methylation and gene expression has prompted an interest in investigating the cellular factors that modify, interpret and regulate methylated signals. In many instances, DNA methylation requires specialized proteins called methyl-CpG binding proteins (MBPs), to read and translate methylated DNA signals into alterations in gene expression, which downstream regulates cellular function. The focus of the project was to evaluate the role of the under investigated zinc finger (ZF)-containing ZBTB family of MBPs in this important process. While sufficient findings from our group and others suggested that the three ZBTB MBPs regulate gene expression that mediate key cellular functions, an extensive analysis for the mechanisms of methylated DNA and protein recognition mediated by each protein remained to be determined.

 

In this project we utilized a combination of biochemical, biophysical, structural and cell-based methodologies to define the molecular mechanisms by which each member of the ZBTB family of MBPs recognize their methylated DNA sites, and to identify their respective protein interacting partners. Findings from our studies have illuminated a number of key aspects for how the three members of the ZBTB MBP family selectively read methylated DNA targets, an essential component in regulation of epigenetic-based transcriptional processes. Specifically, we not only assigned previously unknown functions to each ZF domain within the three ZBTB MBPs, but have also demonstrated that each ZF domain utilizes a unique molecular mechanism to selectively read their methylated DNA or nucleic acid targets by differentially using structural features outside of the core ZF domain to afford this capability. In addition, we identified a novel mechanism for methylated DNA recognition by ZF proteins. This finding expands the field?s understanding for how this important epigenetic mark is selectively distinguished, and suggests that there may be other as of yet unidentified ZF proteins that may be selective readers of methylated DNA sites. Validation of our in vitro findings in human cell lines has provided important new insights for how these proteins selectively recognize genomic sites in a methyl-specific manner to effect transcriptional processes. Further, a long-standing knowledge gap in the MBP and epigenetic field has been correlating the recognition of specific methylated DNA sites to protein assembly recruitment, local chromatin alterations and changes in transcriptional response. Utilizing multiple proteomics mass spectrometry approaches, we have identified a number of previously unknown protein binding partners for the members of the ZBTB MBP family. These findings have opened several new exciting avenues for investigation, and in combination with our enhanced understanding for the molecular mechanisms of methylated DNA recognition, have provided critical new insights into the scope of cellular roles for which this important family of epigenetic transcription factors participate.

 

This project resulted in multiple peer-reviewed publications, with further papers in development. Findings from this project have also been presented in oral and poster form at universities, as well as National conferences/symposia by both the PI and supported trainees. Several high-resolution structures have and soon will be deposited within the publicly available Protein Data Bank (PDB). Multiple graduate and undergraduate students, as well as two postdoctoral fellows were trained in a highly interdisciplinary research program that utilized a broad spectrum of cutting-edge in vitro and cell-based techniques to expand understanding for the mechanisms of epigenetically mediated transcriptional cellular processes. A number of these trainees were women and/or members of underrepresented groups that received an advanced education in the areas of biophysical chemistry, biochemistry, epigenetics and transcription. Additionally, the PI and supported trainees leveraged findings to develop outreach workshops and hands-on activities that were implemented within the University of Utah and local Salt Lake City community. This afforded the opportunity to educate a large number of individuals from diverse ages and backgrounds, including underrepresented groups and budding female scientists, in topics related to biophysical chemistry, epigenetics and transcription. During these workshops students were also informed about our University of Utah undergraduate and graduate programs and the exciting research opportunities available. It is well recognized that the interest of a child in science is best instilled at an early and impressionable age, and it is expected that our implementation of the hands-on activities will have a long-term significant impact on the state?s diversity growth in STEM areas.
